text_of_amendment: The move to secure the ‘rights’ of parents under law is gaining momentum. A new group, Of the People, helped introduce the Parental Rights Amendment (PRA) last year in seven states. title_or_description_from_source: Parental and Family Rights
sponsor_name: American Coalition for Fathers and Children (ACFC) president Stephen Baskerville in "The Liberator"
text_of_amendment: While family law is a state issue, constitutional rights are federal. We still plan to promote federal protection for parental rights. With adequate preparation, we can succeed where others, with a weaker bill, failed. Eventually we would like to see (and we are not alone) a federal constitutional amendment to protect parental and family rights. This would be more comprehensive than the current Marriage Protection Amendment, which is probably too narrow to accomplish even its own purpose and is certainly too limited to protect families, parents, and children from the reach of government intrusion. If the Constitution needs an amendment today to deal with a contingency the framers could not possibly foresee, it is one to protect the integrity of families, the rights of children to be raised by their parents, and the rights of parents to the care and custody of their children

title_or_description_from_source: Parental rights
sponsor_name: Representative Pete Hoekstra of Michigan, quoted in "The Liberator"
text_of_amendment:
SECTION 1
The liberty of parents to direct the upbringing and education of their children is a fundamental right (ACFC endorses adding ‘regardless of marital status’ to the end of this section, thereby extending the amendment’s protection to all parents.)
SECTION 2
Neither the United States nor any state shall infringe upon this right without demonstrating that its governmental interest as applied to the person is of the highest order and not otherwise served.
SECTION 3
Neither treaty nor any source of international law may be employed to supersede, modify, interpret, or apply to the rights guaranteed by this article.
An amendment to the United States Constitution would secure the ultimate liberty that the founders envisioned when our constitution was written. The liberty interest parents have in their offspring must be formally protected. The Supreme Court has ruled that the fundamental right of the parent-child relationship is a right far more precious than property rights.
Let’s do as the Irish have done. Let us state our intention to protect our children and future generations from the misery that unjustified State intervention into familial affairs represents. Our Supreme Court has spoken, yet its opinions are ignored. It’s time to amend our constitution so that there is no misunderstanding that America’s public policy is in full support of the fundamental right of parents to raise and educate their children without unjustified State intervention

text_of_amendment:
1. No person shall hold any office under the United State or any State, City or Town of its Territories and Possessions win owes allegience [sic] to any foreign king, county or individual, regardless of his being a natural or naturalized citizen of the United States. 
2. title_or_description_from_source: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution regarding the right to voluntary school prayer
text_of_amendment: "Nothing in this Constitution shall be construed to prohibit individual or group prayer in public schools or other public institutions. No person shall be required by the United States or by any State to participate in prayer."
notes: This is not the first instance in which Reagan endorsed an amendment pertaining to school prayer, but it seems to be the most explicit and significant among those listed in the Presidential Papers. Prior to and after this statement, he spoke in favor of a similar amendment multiple times.
